FT549101-22_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In The Catcher in the Rye, Holden’s hunting cap is a symbol.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Their Eyes Were Watching God follows Janie on a journey of self-exploration.”

· “Shakespeare’s play King Lear is a personal and political tragedy.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of what complex idea or meaning a symbol reveals in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about what complex idea or meaning a symbol reveals and how the symbol contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The title of Sylvia Plath’s novel The Bell Jar symbolizes both Esther’s spinning thoughts that keep her trapped in her mind and society’s perspective of young women as decorative or delicate objects to be confined.”

· “The appearance of Banquo’s ghost at Macbeth’s banquet symbolizes Macbeth’s increasing guilt and his losing grip on reality, demonstrating Shakespeare’s finer point that people cannot enjoy their status or honors if unfairly, or in this case cruelly, won.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the selected work.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In The Catcher in the Rye, Holden’s hunting cap is a symbol.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Their Eyes Were Watching God follows Janie on a journey of self-exploration.”

· “Shakespeare’s play King Lear is a personal and political tragedy.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of what complex idea or meaning a symbol reveals in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about what complex idea or meaning a symbol reveals and how the symbol contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The title of Sylvia Plath’s novel The Bell Jar symbolizes both Esther’s spinning thoughts that keep her trapped in her mind and society’s perspective of young women as decorative or delicate objects to be confined.”

· “The appearance of Banquo’s ghost at Macbeth’s banquet symbolizes Macbeth’s increasing guilt and his losing grip on reality, demonstrating Shakespeare’s finer point that people cannot enjoy their status or honors if unfairly, or in this case cruelly, won.”

FT549101-22_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response must address the interpretation of the selected work as a whole.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

FT549101-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the poem must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The speaker of the poem has a complex attitude about desire.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “Sir Philip Sidney uses literary elements and techniques to develop a poem about a blind man’s mark.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “‘Thou Blind Man’s Mark’ follows the rhyme scheme and meter of a sonnet.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex attitude toward desire.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In ‘Thou Blind Man’s Mark,’ the speaker, in his wish to destroy desire, ironically strengthens it by creating fourteen lines of images and metaphors that describe its power.”

· “The speaker views desire as an empty promise that doesn’t lead to fulfillment, and virtue as the desire to kill desire. The irony of this perspective is that even having the desire to kill desire keeps the speaker trapped in desire; he can never escape or overpower desire even in virtue and therefore never feel fulfillment.”

· “The speaker’s attitude toward desire shifts from the beginning of the sonnet to the end, reflecting a change in his perspective of desire as an overpowering force to a formidable, but ultimately controllable, enemy.”

The irony of this perspective is that even having the desire to kill desire keeps the speaker trapped in desire; he can never escape or overpower desire even in virtue and therefore never feel fulfillment.”

· “The speaker’s attitude toward desire shifts from the beginning of the sonnet to the end, reflecting a change in his perspective of desire as an overpowering force to a formidable, but ultimately controllable, enemy.”

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the poem contribute to its meaning

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Estrella is portrayed as a complex character through Viramontes’ use of literary elements and techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “Everyone should learn how to use tools, like a hammer and screwdriver, in order to be self-sufficient.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This excerpt includes flashbacks of Estrella’s experiences with teachers at school.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the development of Estrella’s complex character.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Through a combination of rich details, flashbacks, and anecdotes, Viramontes develops Estrella’s character as someone who is eager to learn and yet has been denied access to a meaningful education because of others’ negative assumptions about her.”

· “The series of descriptions of Estrella’s education being stunted repeatedly develops the reader’s expectations that her curiosity may die down, but Viramontes hints throughout the passage at the persistence of her underlying desire to learn which ultimately is rewarded. Through Estrella’s complex character, Viramontes reminds readers that people have greater depths and hidden desires that are not always immediately apparent.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In M. Butterfly, surroundings affect Gallimard and contribute to the meaning of the play.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Silko’s Ceremony tells the story of Tayo returning from WWII.”

· “The novel The Grapes of Wrath follows the Joad family as they move from Oklahoma to California looking for work and a better future.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of how surroundings affect a character in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how surroundings affect a character and contribute to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Isabel Allende’s The House of the Spirits, the political and cultural tension between the upper class and the peasants strengthens Pedro Tercero’s resolve to fight oppression and to hold tightly to his love for Blanca, the daughter of a wealthy conservative politician determined to break up their relationship.”

· “In Sartre’s play No Exit, Garcin, who is stuck in a room in Hell with two other people, comes to confess that he treated his wife poorly, but the suffering of being in this room of Hell is not enough to cause him to stop inflicting pain on others or himself.”

· “Milkman’s solo trip to the south in Song of Solomon, after having spent lived his whole life with his parents, creates a shift in his perspective; his new surroundings result in his having a deeper compassion for others and increased sense of personal responsibility.”

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

FT549104-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Max in ‘Mammita’s Garden Cove’ has complex attitudes toward place.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “In Dabydeen’s short story, the narrator describes Max’s desire to find a job.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This excerpt from ‘Mammita’s Garden Cove’ shifts between Max’s thoughts about the present and the past.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Max’s complex attitudes toward place.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Max’s insecurity about his current living conditions in Canada are emphasized by his recalling bits of dialogue from friends and family, and the desperate, but determined, tone in his inner dialogue to be successful in Canada.”

· “In the uncertainty of Max’s finding a job in Canada, Max swings between romanticizing his previous life in the West Indies and his future in Canada, as a way to make sense of the present discomfort of not having yet achieved his goals.”

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In All My Sons, the contrast of generational viewpoints and values contributes to the meaning of the work.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Danticat’s novel The Dew Breaker is a collection of short stories that can be read as a novel.”

· “The House of Mirth is a satire of the poor behavior of the upper class.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the opposing viewpoints and values of older and younger characters in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the opposing viewpoints and values of older and younger characters contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Antigone, the clash between Antigone and her uncle, King Creon, as to whether Polynices should have a proper burial challenges the reader to consider the potential damage of following the law blindly as opposed to listening to one’s conscience and empathizing with others.”

· “In Achebe’s Things Fall Apart, Okonkwo’s uncompromising prioritization of masculinity as a father and leader of Umuofia prevents him from finding any value in the gentler side of his son Nwoye. Their conflict helps creates a space within which the white missionaries, who offer some relief to Nwoye, are able to gain a foothold in colonizing Umuofia.”

· “In Hurston’s Their Eyes Were Watching God, Nanny’s desire for Janie to be married and financially secure is understandable given her life experience as a former slave, however, it ultimately limits her granddaughter Janie, whose sense of adventure proves more powerful in her self-actualization and contentment with her life.”

Their conflict helps creates a space within which the white missionaries, who offer some relief to Nwoye, are able to gain a foothold in colonizing Umuofia.”

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the poem must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The speaker uses literary techniques to convey his relationship with the characters in his novel.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The poem makes the audience consider the challenges of writing a novel.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “Updike’s purpose in the poem is emphasized by his use of lively diction and strong imagery.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex relationship between the novelist and the characters in the novel.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Updike’s poem ‘Marching Through a Novel,’ the speaker expresses that the tension between caring for his characters and commanding their fates weighs on his conscience despite his commitment to ultimately ending their story.”

· “Through an appreciative tone and militaristic diction, Updike reveals that the novelist’s and characters’ relationship is loving and yet inescapably unequal; it is defined by the characters’ obedience to the novelist and the novelist’s determination to end the book within which they live.”

· “In ‘Marching Through a Novel,’ the novelist acknowledges the desperation of his characters whose lives are subject to his whim, but ultimately he feels little guilt for commanding their plot lines.”

· Oversimplify complexities in the poem.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the poem.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the poem.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Caroline is leaving and entering complex phases of her life.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “The author describes what it means to be eighteen.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The author uses multiple dashes and exclamation points to express her ideas about complex life phases.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex phases of life the protagonist is leaving and entering.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “While adults often idealize childhood and children often idealize adulthood, Brontë presents both phases of life that Caroline is on the threshold of as being equally joyful and challenging.”

· “Through contrast and sharp punctuation, Brontë illuminates how the mysteries of childhood excite the imagination and the mysteries of adulthood crush the imagination in exchange for wisdom.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Absalom, Absalom!, a sibling relationship contributes to the meaning of the novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Henry James’ novella The Turn of the Screw is an example of gothic fiction.”

· “The Piano Lesson, by August Wilson, centers around a brother and sister who can’t agree on whether to sell or keep a piano.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the sibling relationship in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the sibling relationship contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Miller’s play Death of a Salesman, the relationship between Biff and Happy reflects the complicated legacy of their father—the conflict between authentic love and shallow facades.”

· “Lorraine Hansberry’s play A Raisin in the Sun illustrates through the differing opinions of Walter and Beneatha, brother and sister, that socio-political and economic issues that threaten individual dreams, such as racism, can divide a family unless the individuals prioritize the family first.”

· “The relationship of Cordelia, Goneril, and Regan in King Lear provides the audience with several contrasts—virtue and sin, devotion and deception, kindness and selfishness—to emphasize a nihilistic idea that good and evil behavior don’t always receive justice.”

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Alvarez’s use of literary elements conveys the speaker’s complex experience.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “Julia Alvarez’s poem is powerful because of how it presents information.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The poem explores the speaker’s experience of finding a book of poetry she likes.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex experience.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Despite the speaker’s excitement in finding a poet with whom she could identify, Alvarez establishes the speaker as her own person by not allowing her admiration, as described through figurative language, overwhelm her ability to make good decisions based on her reality, as described through concrete language.”

· “In Julia Alvarez’s poem ‘On Not Shoplifting Louise Bogan’s The Blue Estuaries,’ the speaker’s discovery of an unfamiliar writer begins a process of self-discovery—both literary and moral.”

· “The speaker’s temptation to steal the poetry book sets in opposition her desire to have her voice affirmed and her desire to be authentic. Alvarez highlights this through a contemplative tone and varied punctuation.”

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the passage contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the passage contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

FT549112-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Estella’s complexity in Great Expectations is illuminated by her name.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “The Color Purple reveals through Celie the importance of self-expression.”

· “Waiting for Godot focuses on characters waiting for someone who doesn’t ever arrive.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of how the name illuminates the character’s complexity in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the name illuminates the character’s complexity and contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In The Handmaid’s Tale, the protagonist’s name, Offred, is a reminder of her status as property ‘of Fred’ and yet ironic in that her narration of the novel proves that her thoughts and experiences are her own.”

· “In The Tempest, Caliban’s name, a near anagram for cannibal, suggests that Caliban is cruel and uncivilized, and yet because it is not quite an anagram, it also suggests that he is unfairly perceived that way. This reflects how Caliban oscillates between being an unlikeable character and a sympathetic victim.”

· “Gogol’s name in Lahiri’s The Namesake, is symbolic of his struggle with his cultural identity because he doesn’t fully relate to the culture of his Indian parents who named him, the culture of his American friends among whose names his stands out, nor the culture of the Russian author for whom he was named. His name illuminates his experience of feeling like he doesn’t belong.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The speaker uses literary elements and techniques to develop the city as complex.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “Robinson presents London in a poem in a way that readers can relate to if they live in a city.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “Robinson utilizes alliteration in ‘London’s Summer Morning’ as a complement to other devices such as imagery and detail.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex characterization of the city as a source of inspiration for the poet.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the poem ‘London’s Summer Morning,’ the poet characterizes London as a dirty and bustling city which is beautiful because of the Londoners’ industrious spirits.”

· “Robinson illustrates through rich imagery and a lively tone that the mundane details of working life in London can be a source of inspiration because they reveal the realities of life, as opposed to dreams.”

· “The speaker of ‘London’s Summer Morning’ illustrates that the loud noises and activities of London are more than a nuisance that disturb a poet’s sleep; they are, in fact, inspiring because they reflect an energetic approach to work, which sets the poet about writing.”

Restate the prompt

· “In this excerpt from The Inheritance of Loss the mood and setting are particularly complex.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This passage describes a character’s thoughts on loss.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “Desai uses strong diction and vivid imagery throughout the excerpt.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex mood and setting.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Desai uses images of shadow, fragments, and mist in describing the setting to establish a melancholy mood to emphasize Sai’s seeming experience of lost love, the feeling that something is near and beyond reach, or present but not complete.”

· “The rich detail and imagery of the squid, the house, and the garden blur the line between the setting and Sai’s inner world, establishing a mood of confusion and longing.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “F. Scott Fitzgerald aims to teach and delight his readers in The Great Gatsby.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Shakespeare’s The Comedy of Errors centers around the mix-up of two pairs of twins.”

· “In the play “Our Town,” Emily is able to come to a realization about life that others are not.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex pursuit of the dual purposes of instructing and pleasing the reader in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the complex pursuit of the dual purposes—instructing and pleasing the reader—contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Zora Neale Hurston endears Janie, the protagonist of Their Eyes Were Watching God, to the reader through her loving and idealistic nature, which makes her not only a delightful character to cheer for throughout the novel but also a powerful medium for Hurston’s instruction on how to live—because people learn more deeply from those they love.”

· “Kesey’s One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest is a prime example of how humor encourages original thinking; McMurphy’s bold and entertaining antics in the novel teach the other patients and the readers that their dignity is important.”

· “In Moby-Dick, Melville’s story of adventure and humorous wit provide relief from Ahab’s maniacal pursuit of the whale and make the pointlessness of a single-minded obsession an easier lesson to absorb.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “James uses literary elements to depict the three characters and their relationships with each other.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “An important theme in this excerpt from ‘The Pupil’ is social class.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “Through offering the reader a glimpse of each character’s perspective, Henry James reveals who Pemberton, Mrs. Moreen, and Morgan are and how they relate.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the three characters and the relationships among them.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Mrs. Moreen’s and Morgan’s social class affords them the luxury of being able to focus their attention on their own emotions and ignore good manners; this inhibits their ability to authentically relate to Pemberton who hesitates to discuss matters necessary for his livelihood for fear of appearing vulgar.”

· “Morgan’s disrespect for his mother signals the necessity of Pemberton, with his practical nature and gentle manners, to teach Morgan what Mrs. Moreen, in her extravagant leisure, could not.”

· “Pemberton’s modest attitude toward tutoring, Mrs. Moreen’s relief for finding a tutor, and Morgan’s disrespect for his mother’s efforts highlight the cultural differences of Pemberton’s and the Moreens’ social classes which make Pemberton feel unwelcome.”

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The novel A Gesture Life raises a central question that contributes to the meaning of the work.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Alias Grace, by Margaret Atwood, is a historical fiction novel based on the life of Grace Marks who was accused of murder.”

· “Dreiser’s novel Sister Carrie tells the story of a young woman, Carrie, who moves from Wisconsin to Chicago and then to New York.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the central question the work raises and the extent to which it offers any answers in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the central question the work raises and the extent to which it offers any answers contribute to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Through the consequences of Oedipus’ arrogance, Sophocles reveals humans have some control over their destiny, but not full control, leaving the audience with the unanswered question of just how much control do humans have over their lives.”

· “O’Brien’s The Things They Carried challenges the audience to consider whether factual accuracy or emotional authenticity is more important; his blurring the lines between truth and fiction in each chapter suggests they are both important and establishes his novel as both fiction and memoir.”

Restate the prompt

· “In Anna Karenina, Anna’s mind is pulled in two directions creating internal conflict.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Jane Eyre follows the life of Jane from childhood through to adulthood.”

· “Hansberry’s play A Raisin in the Sun explores how racism can complicate or obstruct the pursuit of one’s dreams.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the conflict within a character between two competing forces in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the conflict within a character between two competing forces contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The conflict between Macbeth’s ambition and guilt ultimately drive him to madness, suggesting that morality is more powerful than any position of power.”

· “In The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn, Huck struggles to make sense of society’s racist institutions and his friendship with Jim, a runaway slave; this internal conflict reveals the absurdity of racism and the social pressure to conform to society’s expectations, despite their cruelty and inhumanity.”

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response must address the interpretation of the selected work as a whole.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning[COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

FT549157-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

o.d: The response demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

FT549163-22_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Jewett uses techniques to develop Sylvia’s adventure.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This excerpt highlights the value of taking risks.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This passage includes beautiful imagery of nature.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the young heroine’s adventure.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Jewett’s use of figurative language and multiple series of dependent clauses in long sentences creates suspense as to the whether Sylvia will be successful, ultimately heightening the sense of accomplishment when she reaches the top of the tree.”

· “The personification of nature and the assigning of nature’s qualities to Sylvia suggest that Sylvia’s feat in climbing the tree was the product of a mutual love between her and nature.”

· “Jewett develops Sylvia’s adventure into a story of strength and beauty by making comparisons between the nobility of the tree and Sylvia.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the passage.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Restate the prompt

· “Jewett uses techniques to develop Sylvia’s adventure.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This excerpt highlights the value of taking risks.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This passage includes beautiful imagery of nature.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the young heroine’s adventure.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Jewett’s use of figurative language and multiple series of dependent clauses in long sentences creates suspense as to the whether Sylvia will be successful, ultimately heightening the sense of accomplishment when she reaches the top of the tree.”

· “The personification of nature and the assigning of nature’s qualities to Sylvia suggest that Sylvia’s feat in climbing the tree was the product of a mutual love between her and nature.”

· “Jewett develops Sylvia’s adventure into a story of strength and beauty by making comparisons between the nobility of the tree and Sylvia.”

o.af:

o.d:

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Waiting for Godot, Godot’s absence affects the other characters.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Shakespeare’s play Hamlet explores the themes of indecision and madness.”

· “The Mayor of Casterbridge reveals that the past cannot be escaped or erased.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the effect of a character who appears briefly or not at all in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the effect of a character who appears briefly or not at all contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Captain Ahab, in Melville’s novel Moby-Dick is so obsessed with exacting revenge on the elusive whale Moby-Dick that he loses perspective and drives his crew and himself to destruction; through this, Melville conveys that seeking revenge is a self-destructive process.”

· “In Lahiri’s The Namesake, set late in the 20th century, the 19th century Russian writer, Nikolai Gogol, becomes symbolic in Ashoke’s mind of a second chance at life, and his looming presence as the inspiration for the name of Ashoke’s son, Gogol, becomes ironically a burden for Gogol, who cannot relate to his parents, his peers, or his namesake.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Eliot uses literary elements and techniques to convey her complex views on leisure.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “Leisure is different during the 1800s than it is today.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “Eliot’s use of imagery features in this passage about leisure.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Eliot’s complex views on “old Leisure” and on leisure in the society of her own time.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Through personifying leisure itself, Eliot conveys her nostalgia for a time when leisure was rooted in enjoyment of the senses as opposed to a thinking task.”

· “Eliot’s detailed contrast of ‘old Leisure’ and modern leisure reveal how modernization has advanced the fields of technology, philosophy, art, and literature, but at the expense of appreciating life’s simple pleasures.”

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Hardy uses literary techniques to showcase the complex relationship between Henchard and Elizabeth-Jane.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “Reuniting with family after estrangement can be challenging.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “In this passage, Henchard uses a sharp tone with Elizabeth-Jane.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex relationship between Michael Henchard and his daughter Elizabeth-Jane.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The contrast between Hardy’s approving tone and Henchard’s bitter criticism of Elizabeth-Jane for traits common to his previous social class emphasize that Henchard’s love for his daughter is conditional and profoundly hindered by his ego and ambition.”

· “The irony of Henchard’s sharp reproach of his daughter and her gentle acceptance of him reveal that despite his higher social status, she demonstrates greater social graces. Henchard’s recognition of this increases his dislike of her and only deepens their estrangement.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the passage.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Hardy uses literary techniques to showcase the complex relationship between Henchard and Elizabeth-Jane.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “Reuniting with family after estrangement can be challenging.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “In this passage, Henchard uses a sharp tone with Elizabeth-Jane.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex relationship between Michael Henchard and his daughter Elizabeth-Jane.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The contrast between Hardy’s approving tone and Henchard’s bitter criticism of Elizabeth-Jane for traits common to his previous social class emphasize that Henchard’s love for his daughter is conditional and profoundly hindered by his ego and ambition.”

· “The irony of Henchard’s sharp reproach of his daughter and her gentle acceptance of him reveal that despite his higher social status, she demonstrates greater social graces. Henchard’s recognition of this increases his dislike of her and only deepens their estrangement.”

FT549231-22_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the passage.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning[COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the passage contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the passage contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

FT549231-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In A Doll’s House, deception is a theme that contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “‘The Blind Assassin is structured in a way that includes a novel within the novel.”

· “The family relationships in The Burgess Boys are intense.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the character’s complex motives and deception in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the character’s complex motives and deception contribute to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Abigail Williams’s deception in The Crucible, while morally wrong, is born out of a fierce instinct for self-preservation, which highlights some of the challenges of growing up female in a misogynistic society.”

· “Amir’s framing of Hassan in The Kite Runner hinges on his inability to confront his guilt for not helping Hassan in a previous dangerous encounter and his desperate desire for his father’s approval. Amir’s avoidance of these difficult emotions allows him to hurt a friend he loves and in turn prolongs his inner conflict into adulthood, proving that emotions cannot be outrun.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Walcott uses literary techniques to convey the complex experience of the speaker visiting the elderly storyteller.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The setting of the Caribbean gives the poem color and texture.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The speaker’s experience is emphasized by Walcott’s masterful use of metaphor and imagery.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex experience.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the poem ‘XIV,’ Walcott’s shift from menacing details to vibrant personification reveals the speaker’s fear of the elderly storyteller transforming into gratitude and awe.”

· “In ‘XIV,’ the speaker’s trepidation in visiting the storyteller shifts into a curiosity that ultimately gives way to an appreciation for the legacy the storyteller passes on to the next generation. This is emphasized by Walcott’s shifts in tone and use of light imagery.”

· “The experience of listening to the storyteller’s stories diminish the speaker’s feelings of being helpless or alone and connect him to his family and his history. The poet’s contrast of threatening images in the opening lines with images of warmth and unity in the concluding lines reflect this.”

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Wuthering Heights, Heathcliff’s cruelty is revealing of his character.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “The Bluest Eye describes the tragedy of young Pecola’s life.”

· “Melville’s Billy Budd focuses on a sailor’s relationships with other sailors aboard ship.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of what the cruelty reveals about the perpetrator and/or victim in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about what the cruelty reveals about the perpetrator and/or victim and how the cruelty contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Shakespeare’s Othello, Iago’s cruel manipulation of his friend Othello stems from his jealousy and highlights how revenge serves only to destroy the aggrieved, the susceptible, and the innocent.”

· “While Claire Zachanassian’s demand for Alfred Ill’s death in exchange for her million-dollar donation to the bankrupt town seems exceptionally cruel in The Visit, it also reveals the extent of her pain at his betrayal many years ago and demonstrates that cruelty begets cruelty.”

· “Dimmesdale’s cowardice in taking responsibility for his relationship with Hester Prynne in The Scarlet Letter is a cruelty that Melville condemns and that he contrasts with Hester’s strength to withstand society’s ostracism alone.”

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning[COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the poem must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The poet uses literary elements to convey the speaker’s complex attitude toward his lover.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “Gascoigne’s poem reminds readers of the damage of deceit.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The structure of ‘For That He Looked Not upon Her’ is a sonnet which leads into the speaker’s final expression in the couplet.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex attitude of the speaker.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the poem, Gascoigne conveys through analogies and an indirect approach that the speaker’s misery following a loved one’s deceit is deeply painful, but survivable.”

· “The speaker’s anger toward presumably an untrustworthy lover is mitigated by a fear of getting hurt again and conveyed through metaphors, a gentle tone, and the structured meter.”

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In The Awakening, Edna’s values are illuminated by what she sacrifices.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “In Toni Morrison’s Beloved, Sethe is haunted by her past.”

· “Wharton’s Ethan Frome depicts the protagonist, Ethan, as incredibly unhappy in his marriage.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of how a particular sacrifice illuminates a character’s values in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how a particular sacrifice illuminates a character’s values and contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Colum McCann’s novel Let the Great World Spin, Corrigan sacrifices his personal safety to defend the humanity of the prostitutes in his neighborhood; in doing so, he is subjected to violence, which illustrates how dangerous and yet necessary it is to do the right thing.”

· “Each day in Ondaatje’s novel The English Patient, Kip, an Indian sapper working for the British government in WWII, risks his life seeking and defusing bombs to protect the lives of others, even when others wish harm on themselves or others; his willingness to sacrifice his life to protect life serves as a striking and inspiring contrast to the collective madness of World War II.”

· “In Their Eyes Were Watching God, Janie sacrifices the town’s approval by pursuing her love with Tea Cake, and it is exactly this risk that strengthens her voice and happiness with life.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The woman and her situation are portrayed through Lawrence’s skillful use of literary techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This excerpt reveals the importance of seeking new experiences.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This passage, narrated in third person, compares the lives of the Brangwens and the vicar.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the woman and her situation.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Through the woman’s interior dialogue and contrasting description, Lawrence reveals the woman to be unsatisfied with the insular nature of farming life; she desires worldly knowledge as a means to have greater influence on the world around her.”

· “The woman’s recognition of the limitations of her family and her appreciation of the vicar’s traits initially present her as a trapped, unhappy woman; however, her deep consideration of her ideas suggests she will find a way to improve and expand her situation.”
