· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Bellow’s The Adventures of Augie March, a single moment shapes the character of Augie March in the bildungsroman.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “All the Pretty Horses uses an unconventional writing style to express John Grady’s coming of age.”

· “Important themes in Roy’s The God of Small Things include love, discrimination, and betrayal.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the pivotal moment in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the pivotal moment contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The moment Briony falsely accuses Robbie Turner in Atonement confirms her power and privilege at a young age and riddles her with guilt for the rest of her life, highlighting how some people, despite increasing maturity, are still willing to allow others’ lives to remain in ruins instead of face social embarrassment.”

· “In The Catcher in the Rye, Holden’s visit with his younger sister Phoebe challenges his disillusionment with growing up and is the pivotal moment that drives Holden to accept that his feelings about adulthood are perhaps immature, despite how flawed the adult world may be.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the poem must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Lee conveys the complex relationship of the father and son through his use of literary elements and techniques.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “‘A Story’ is a poignant poem that deals with the age-old emotions of parenting.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “Li-Young Lee uses italics in the poem to help convey the complex relationship of the father and son.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex relationship of the father and son.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Lee’s poem ‘A Story,’ the poet conveys through the contrast of dialogue and silence the underlying love of a father and son that is not always logically understood.”

· “Lee expresses a father’s fear that his silence will be misunderstood by his son as a lack of love and also negates that worry as a projection into the future; the worry is imagined and the love is in the silence of present moment.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Eliot uses techniques to portray the complex relationship of Rosamund and Lydgate.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This excerpt reminds readers to pay attention to their finances.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “Eliot’s use of dialogue and imagery reveal the inner thoughts of the couple who have a complex relationship.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex relationship of the husband and wife.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The financial difficulties that Rosamund and Tertius encounter expose a major challenge in their relationship—Rosamund’s trusting idealism and Tertius’ proud sense of responsibility—which threatens their ability to communicate effectively.”

· “Although Lydgate admits to being reckless with their finances, he does not see his wife as his equal, despite her willingness to partner with him in the face of money troubles; Eliot conveys this through tonal shifts between gentleness and sharpness and detailed description.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In McCarthy’s All the Pretty Horses, John Grady’s understanding of justice contributes to an interpretation of the novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Native Son explores how racial oppression is reflected in the justice system.”

· “In Dostoyevsky’s Crime and Punishment, Rodion is racked with guilt and paranoia for having committed murder.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of a character’s understanding and pursuit of justice in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how a character’s understanding and pursuit of justice contribute to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Oedipus Rex’s haste in cursing the murderer of King Laius causes the audience to cringe because of his unwitting curse upon himself; but his determination in bringing justice to Thebes and his acceptance of his own punishment prove the depth of his commitment to doing what he believes is fair and right.”

· “In Atonement, Briony Tallis’ understanding of justice is stunted by her self-interest, which explains why she takes satisfaction in fictionalizing Robbie’s life in her novel as a way to exonerate him and atone for her fallacious accusation without actually having to risk anything herself.”

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

FT549245-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

o.d: The response demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.

FT549246-22_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the poem must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Waniek employs literary techniques to convey the complex meanings the speaker attributes to the Century Quilt.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The speaker had a close relationship with Mama.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “Waniek’s use of color and shapes is important in the poem.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex meanings that the speaker attributes to The Century Quilt.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the poem, the speaker alleviates her sadness from not inheriting Meema’s blanket by finding a quilt she likes and imagining that her experience of the quilt will mirror that of Meema’s resting under her blanket and dreaming of her family.”

· “Despite The Century Quilt not being a family heirloom like Meema’s blanket, she finds symbolic meaning in the various colors and the pattern of leaves on the quilt as celebrating her family’s love across generations, across race, and across time.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the poem.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Waniek employs literary techniques to convey the complex meanings the speaker attributes to the Century Quilt.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The speaker had a close relationship with Mama.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “Waniek’s use of color and shapes is important in the poem.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex meanings that the speaker attributes to The Century Quilt.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the poem, the speaker alleviates her sadness from not inheriting Meema’s blanket by finding a quilt she likes and imagining that her experience of the quilt will mirror that of Meema’s resting under her blanket and dreaming of her family.”

· “Despite The Century Quilt not being a family heirloom like Meema’s blanket, she finds symbolic meaning in the various colors and the pattern of leaves on the quilt as celebrating her family’s love across generations, across race, and across time.”

FT549246-22_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the poem.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on summary or description of a poem rather than specific details or techniques.

Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the poem contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the poem to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the poem contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the poem to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the poem.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Edgeworth uses literary techniques to develop Clarence’s complex character.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This passage reveals the efforts people take to make themselves attractive to others.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “Edgeworth makes use of detailed description and long sentences in the passage.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Clarence Hervey’s complex character.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Clarence’s fear of his attraction to Belinda is hypocritical and rooted in vanity; he suspects her of ‘artifice,’ and yet he aims to charm all his companions by taking cue from their interests.”

· “Edgeworth develops the tension between Clarence’s pride and insecurity through striking contrasts and detailed description that reveal him to be charmed by someone who has the potential to disarm him of his sense of superiority.”

Notes for this rubric row:

  • The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

  • The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

  • For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

  • The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

  • A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Only restate the prompt.

  • Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

  • “In Doctor Zhivago, exile contributes to the meaning of the novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

  • “The Odyssey focuses on Odysseus’ journey back to Ithaca after the Trojan War.”

  • “The story of Snow Falling on Cedars is relayed through flashbacks.”

Responses that earn this point:

  • Provide a defensible interpretation of the character’s experience with exile as both alienating and enriching in the selected work.

OR

  • Make a claim about how the character’s experience with exile is both alienating and enriching and how this experience contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

  • “In Adichie’s Americanah, Ifemelu, having moved from Nigeria, experiences American racism as a form of exile within an already foreign country. The difficulties of being true to herself in this context challenge her to explore where she may be inauthentic elsewhere in her life and ultimately help deepen her sense of self.”

  • “Cordelia’s unnecessary exile in King Lear allows her to hold on to her moral principles but prevents her from being able to protect her father from Regan’s and Goneril’s treachery. The needlessness of her exile leads to the demise of their family and the nation and emphasizes the importance of sincere and direct communication.”

Restate the prompt

· “In this excerpt, Petry develops Lutie’s complex relationship to the urban setting through literary elements and techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This passage explores the challenges of apartment hunting.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “Petry uses personification and imagery to depict the setting.”-

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Lutie Johnson’s complex relationship to the urban setting.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Unlike the other pedestrians, Lutie responds to the disruptive and demoralizing setting of 116th Street with a calm determination that suggests a power opposite in nature to that of the setting.”

· “Petry’s vivid description of the annoyances the setting wreaks on the city folk establishes it as an inhospitable place to live. Yet, Lutie’s persistence through these annoyances reveals a focus immune to external forces.”

Restate the prompt

· “In this excerpt, Petry develops Lutie’s complex relationship to the urban setting through literary elements and techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This passage explores the challenges of apartment hunting.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “Petry uses personification and imagery to depict the setting.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Lutie Johnson’s complex relationship to the urban setting.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Unlike the other pedestrians, Lutie responds to the disruptive and demoralizing setting of 116th Street with a calm determination that suggests a power opposite in nature to that of the setting.”

· “Petry’s vivid description of the annoyances the setting wreaks on the city folk establishes it as an inhospitable place to live. Yet, Lutie’s persistence through these annoyances reveals a focus immune to external forces.”

FT549250-22_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the passage.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the passage contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the passage contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

FT549250-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Desai employs techniques to portray Arun’s complex experience.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This passage illustrates that not everyone likes the beach.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “In this passage, Desai makes use of point of view and imagery.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Arun’s complex experience.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the host family’s efforts to include Arun in a fun family activity, they ironically make him feel annoyed and awkward. Despite this, he acquiesces to their invitation in an effort to support their happiness.”

· “Desai’s contrasts between images of social structure and the wilderness emphasize that Arun’s discomfort in going to the beach is close but not enough to overcome his respect for social customs.”

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Don Quixote, the relation between Sancho and Don Quixote contributes to the meaning of the novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “In All the King’s Men, Willie Stark’s character was partially inspired by a real person in history.”

· “The Color Purple includes characters who grow and develop throughout the course of the story.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the relation between the foil and the major character in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the relation between the foil and the major character contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Like Ifemeulu, the protagonist of Adichie’s Americanah, Kosi, Obinze’s wife, feels the pressure to change her behavior to adapt to her surroundings; however, Kosi’s value of appearances reflects a sharp distinction from Ifemelu’s value of authenticity, which ultimately sets her on a path of personal acceptance and fulfillment.”

· “In Shelley’s Frankenstein, Walton, who shares with Frankenstein a passionate desire for knowledge, is able to course-correct in a dangerous situation unlike Frankenstein because he takes greater responsibility for his actions.”

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Cry, the Beloved Country, Kumalo has a complex relationship with the past.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Tess of the d’Urbervilles deals with the theme of injustice.”

· “Throughout Chang-Rae Lee’s novel Native Speaker, Henry Park struggles with his identity.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the character’s complex relationship to the past in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the character’s complex relationship to the past contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Cunningham’s The Hours, Laura Brown’s desire for the freedom she felt in her past to bury her nose in books before marriage and motherhood, before others depended on her, reflects her disillusionment with her current reality as a traditional 1950s housewife and mother.”

· “Hana, a nurse during WWII, commits to taking care of Almásy, a mysterious burned patient, in The English Patient as a way to heal from the grief of having lost her father and to find a sense of purpose in the present when her past feels too overwhelming.”

Notes for this rubric row:

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning[COMMENTARY]
o.af:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Warren uses literary techniques to convey the complex mood and meaning of the scene in his poem ‘Evening Hawk.’”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The poem depicts the flight of a hawk during an avalanche.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “‘Evening Hawk’ consists of five uneven stanzas.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the scene’s complex mood and meaning.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the poem ‘Evening Hawk,’ Warren conveys through the symbolism of the hawk the experience of life as uncertain and at the mercy of larger forces, such as nature and death.”

· “The mood of ‘Evening Hawk’ shifts from admiration of the hawk’s daring feats to a philosophical recognition of nature’s superior power. Through the image of the hawk, Warren reminds the audience that humankind is at the mercy of nature, despite any glorious achievements.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The values of the characters and the nature of their society are illustrated through Wilde’s use of literary technique.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This excerpt invites the audience to consider social graces.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The excerpt includes witty banter and word play.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the values of the characters and the nature of their society.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The conversation of the three characters reveals the women’s concern for social propriety and Lord Darlington’s desire to escape being confined by custom. Their contrasting values highlight the different rules and expectations for men and women in their society.”

· “Although all three characters value life and their relationships seriously, the nature of their society requires women to act cautiously to preserve their safety and reputations and requires men to hide their true concerns to avoid vulnerability.”

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

FT549278-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In A Gesture Life, the tension between outward conformity and inward questioning contributes to interpreting the novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “‘Obasan explores Canada’s internment of people of Japanese descent during World War II.”

· “1984 is a dystopian novel written by Orwell in 1949.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the tension between outward conformity and inward questioning in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the tension between outward conformity and inward questioning contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Antonio’s questioning nature in Anaya’s Bless Me, Ultima comes into tension with the pressure he feels to conform to the conflicting cultural traditions and personal wishes of his parents. This tension drives him, with the support of Ultima, to develop more complex understandings of the world while also respecting the traditions and customs that can at times feel insufficient.”

· “Ethan Frome’s prioritization of conforming to the institution of marriage over his own inner questioning of his marriage leads his depression only to deepen and inspire his own demise, revealing the challenge of being true to both one’s self and others.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Gallant develops social commentary through literary elements and techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This passage explores the relationship of an engaged couple.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “Gallant employs an omniscient point of view in this passage.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the social commentary.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Through the engagement of Carol and Howard, Gallant critiques society’s hypocrisy in simultaneously setting expectations for romance, preaching that love is an ‘illusion,’ and instilling a fear of being alone.”

· “The impetus for Carol’s and Howard’s engagement is their alarming realization that they have not found love on the timeline that society deems respectable. Gallant criticizes this social pressure to marry within a certain time by illustrating how it can drive people into a lifelong commitment that may be loveless.”

Examples that earn this point:

Gallant criticizes this social pressure to marry within a certain time by illustrating how it can drive people into a lifelong commitment that may be loveless.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Fences, suffering is caused by a tragic figure.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “‘Anna Karenina is a tragic story about love.”

· “The legacy of suffering from the institution of slavery plays a significant role in Beloved.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the suffering brought upon others by a tragic figure in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the suffering brought upon others by a tragic figure contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Sophocles’ play Antigone, the suffering of Haemon, Eurydice, and eventually Creon following the death of Antigone establishes the importance of moral courage and humility over that of order and law.”

· “As king, Macbeth, a once noble soldier and thane, drives Scotland into national disorder and despair as a result of his shifting focus from national service to personal ambition and self-protection. Scotland’s suffering emphasizes how dire and far-reaching the consequences are for a leader to sacrifice concern for others for personal gain.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Hardy conveys the speaker’s attitude toward the ship’s sinking through his skillful use of literary techniques.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The poem explores themes that are still relevant today when applied to other situations.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The poem is structured by eleven three-lined stanzas.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex attitude toward the sinking of the ship.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the poem, the speaker blames the sinking of the Titanic on human pride and at the same time suggests the ship was predetermined to meet the iceberg.”

· “The imagery and comparison of the ship to the iceberg reveal the speaker’s perspective that both nature and human-made objects can grow and increase in stature and beauty, but nature has none of the vanity in creation that brings about destruction.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the poem.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Hardy conveys the speaker’s attitude toward the ship’s sinking through his skillful use of literary techniques.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The poem explores themes that are still relevant today when applied to other situations.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The poem is structured by eleven three-lined stanzas.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex attitude toward the sinking of the ship.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the poem, the speaker blames the sinking of the Titanic on human pride and at the same time suggests the ship was predetermined to meet the iceberg.”

· “The imagery and comparison of the ship to the iceberg reveal the speaker’s perspective that both nature and human-made objects can grow and increase in stature and beauty, but nature has none of the vanity in creation that brings about destruction.”

FT549293-22_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the poem.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on summary or description of a poem rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the poem contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the poem to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the poem contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the poem to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the poem.

FT549293-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the poem could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the poem comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the poem.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the poem.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the poem.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In The Age of Innocence, Ellen is a morally ambiguous character and that ambiguity contributes to the meaning of the novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Gothe’s play Faust explores the tension and union of reason and emotion.”

· “Morrison explores the moral ambiguity of love in Sula.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of how a character can be viewed as morally ambiguous in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how a character can be viewed as morally ambiguous and how the moral ambiguity contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Shylock in The Merchant of Venice appears both cruel in his revenge and understandably wounded by the persecution he has experienced. The moral ambiguity of his character suggests that he is not best understood as villain or victim, but rather as human.”

· “The moral ambiguity of Gatsby in Fitzgerald’s The Great Gatsby—is his pursuit of love admirable or does his corruption matter—leads readers to question what they can and can’t morally excuse. However, Fitzgerald ultimately asserts that morals are less of a driving force than hope.”

· “In Plath’s The Bell Jar, the combination of Esther’s innate sensitivity, keen insights into misogyny, and lack of opportunity for consensual sexual exploration makes her descent into mental illness a more logical consequence of her environment as opposed to a consequence of her biology or psychology.”

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The mystery of Great Expectations contributes to the meaning of the novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Bleak House is narrated by both Esther and an omniscient narrator.”

· “The Trial, written by Kafka, focuses on the experiences of Joseph K.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the investigation of the mystery in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the investigation of the mystery contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The investigation of Nouf’s death in Ferraris’ novel Finding Nouf invites Nayir to learn about the pressures, limitations, and desires of Saudi Arabian women which helps him not only solve Nouf’s case, but also see the world around him more clearly.”

· “In The English Patient, the slow unraveling of the mystery of the English patient’s identity is the product of gentle curiosity and a listening ear, as opposed to a direct line of questioning. The lack of urgency in solving the mystery, despite the possibility of Hana treating the enemy, reveals her greater concern for human life than national identity.”

Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response must address the interpretation of the selected work as a whole.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning[COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The poem conveys the speaker’s response to the toad’s death through Wilbur’s use of literary devices.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “‘The Death of a Toad’ encourages the audience to prioritize safety.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The poem’s AABCBC rhyme scheme helps articulate meaning.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex response to the death of a toad.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the poem ‘The Death of a Toad,’ the poet conveys the speaker’s fascination with the toad’s experience and also desire for emotional distance from it.”

· “The rhyming and the lighthearted tone reveal the speaker’s sense of superiority to this small life of the toad. The imagery, however, illustrates the speaker’s understanding of death as a greater power than he on the lawn mower.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Kogawa uses techniques to convey the narrator’s complex attitude.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “Kogawa’s writing makes readers want to learn more about World War II history.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This passage makes use of metaphors, dialogue, and details.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the narrator’s complex attitude toward the past.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The narrator’s painful memories of being relocated during WWII are also marked by moments of tenderness which contribute to her feelings of being closely connected to others despite the inhumane treatment of Japanese Canadians.”

· “Kogawa uses figurative language to express the collective suffering of the Japanese Canadians and uses narrative description to detail her journey on the train. These techniques help convey the narrator’s appreciation of her past as part of a collective experience and also individual to her.”

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Romeo and Juliet, their marriage reveals the values of their families.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “The Joy Luck Club examines the experience of immigration.”

· “Harold Pinter’s play The Birthday Party centers around a piano player’s birthday party getting interrupted.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of what the scene reveals about the values of the characters or society in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about what the scene reveals about the values of the characters or society and how it contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In The Member of the Wedding, set in the 1940s, the scene after Frankie’s brother’s wedding reveals Frankie’s pain in the recognition that society values a binary perspective on relationships more than her desire to belong. The scene raises the question, without answering it, as to whether accepting this value is part of growing up or a social construct that can be isolating.”

· “The scene of Ophelia’s funeral in Hamlet exposes the characters’ value of male emotions over those of women, as her death is the result of men trying to control their fears by controlling her and their turning her funeral into a contest of which man is in more pain when they should be honoring her life.”

· “In The Member of the Wedding, set in the 1940s, the scene after Frankie’s brother’s wedding reveals Frankie’s pain in the recognition that society values a binary perspective on relationships more than her desire to belong. The scene raises the question, without answering it, as to whether accepting this value is part of growing up or a social construct that can be isolating.”

· “The scene of Ophelia’s funeral in Hamlet exposes the characters’ value of male emotions over those of women, as her death is the result of men trying to control their fears by controlling her and their turning her funeral into a contest of which man is in more pain when they should be honoring her life.”

FT549309-22_rubric_category_1.s:

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response must address the interpretation of the selected work as a whole.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

FT549309-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Hawthorne draws upon several literary elements and techniques to create a complex portray of Judge Pyncheon.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This passage explores the themes of truth and fairness.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This excerpt uses punctuation and juxtaposition to emphasize ideas.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex character of Judge Pyncheon.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Hawthorne portrays Judge Pyncheon to be someone who is concerned more with order and public opinion than moral or just behavior.”

· “Hawthorne’s paragraph-long list of Pyncheon’s admirable qualities is swiftly undercut by a critique of Pyncheon’s lack of self-reflection, which renders him unable to decipher between his true self and his reputation. This inability suggests his admirable qualities are only for appearance’s sake.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In All the Pretty Horses, John Grady’s spiritual reassessment contributes to an interpretation of the novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “A Portrait of the Artist as a Young Man explores Dedalus’ thoughts about religion and tradition.”

· “In The Stone Angel, Hagar experiences complex emotions that she doesn’t always show.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of a “spiritual reassessment or moral reconciliation” in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the “spiritual reassessment or moral reconciliation” contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Janie’s return to Eatonville, in Hurston’s Their Eyes Were Watching God, signifies her spiritual reassessment of love. No longer does she seek other’s approval to feel loved. Rather, her return illustrates that self-love is the highest form of love.”

· “In the end of The Woman Warrior, Kingston’ spiritual reconciliation of her relationship with her mother and her bicultural experience as American and Chinese is symbolized by her talk-story that blends her mother’s story with her own in an authentic expression of self that blurs fact and fiction and embraces, rather than rejects, the complexities of her identity.”

Restate the prompt

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The poem challenges the audience to consider their emotions.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The poem focuses on a single metaphor.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex attitude of the speaker.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Bradstreet conveys the speaker’s deep distress at not having been able to polish her book by comparing the book to a child whom the mother loves but cannot improve.”

· “The harsh and critical nature of the speaker towards the imaginary child reveals the extent to which she critiques her own written work, explaining why she feels so desperate with the book now out of her hands.”
