o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The literary elements develop Quoyle in a complex way.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This excerpt discusses the effect of family dynamics.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This passage describes Quoyle through imagery and specific detail.

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex portrait of Quoyle.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “With short punchy sentences and unflattering description, Proulx portrays Quoyle as an unattractive and unsuccessful man, yet also a generally sympathetic character who persists despite discouragement.”

· “Quoyle is a lonely and confused man, the victim of his family’s ridicule, who desires finding acceptance and doesn’t know how.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the passage.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Restate the prompt

· “The literary elements develop Quoyle in a complex way.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This excerpt discusses the effect of family dynamics.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This passage describes Quoyle through imagery and specific detail.”

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex portrait of Quoyle.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

FT549658-22_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the passage.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the passage contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the passage contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Allende’s The House of the Spirits follows the lives of multiple generations within the same family.”

· “The Playboy of the Western World is a play that inspired riots because some people thought it was immoral.”

Responses that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation of why the character keeps or reveals a secret in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about why the character keeps or reveals a secret and how that decision contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In The Namesake, Gogol complains about his name for years. Yet, his father Ashoke keeps the personal meaning of Gogol’s name a secret until Gogol is mature enough to appreciate his father’s near-death experience and his courage to begin a new life in the United States.”

· “In ‘Master Harold’. . . and the boys, Sam reveals why years ago he made the kite to illustrate how misdirected Hally’s anger is and to express the compassion he has always felt for Hally whose alcoholic father is the real source of his anger. Sam’s secret reminds the audience that a generosity of spirit is available to everyone regardless of status or position in society.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Dreaming in Cuban is set in both Cuba and the United States.”

· “Dene in Orange’s novel There There aims to capture people’s stories on video.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of a character’s response to a cultural collision in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the character’s response to a cultural collision contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Things Fall Apart, Okonkwo’s resistance of the white missionaries’ attempts to colonize Umuofia is unwavering, even when the perspective of his clan is shifting. His resistance signifies that even if the clan complies with the missionaries, he will not allow himself to be colonized.”

· “Gatsby’s denial of the differing values of new money and old money cultures explains why even after the fight with Tom he continues to hold on to an impossible fantasy of a life with Daisy.”

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the social commentary.

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Through Wilson’s impetus to visit Mr. Carson, the lavish details of his house, and the servants’ anecdotes, Gaskell critiques the disparity of wealth that affords the upper class the luxury of indulgence amidst others’ suffering or discomfort.”

· “Gaskell focuses the passage on the servants’ experiences and opinions, of which the Carsons are seemingly uninterested, to develop her criticism of the wealthy’s self-absorption.”

· “In One Hundred Years of Solitude, a death illuminates meaning in Gabriel García Márquez’s novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Esi Edugyan’s novel Washington Black is a bildungsroman that tells the story of Washington Black as he escapes slavery.”

· “As I Lay Dying is a Southern Gothic novel narrated by many different characters.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of a specific death in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how a specific death contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The death of over 100,000 people in the firebombing of Dresden and the survival of Billy Pilgrim, the weak and passive protagonist in Vonnegut’s Slaughterhouse-Five, assert the indiscriminate nature of life and death in war and reminds readers not to equate either with glory or defeat.”

· “Hagar’s death in Song of Solomon highlights the spiritual necessity of finding self-worth from within rather than from ownership or manipulation of others.”

· “Although Iago is to blame for his vengeful deception, Desdemona’s death is the tragic result of Othello’s valuing Iago’s word more than his wife’s.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:

o.d:

o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Hughes uses literary techniques to convey the speaker’s complex attitudes toward nature and the artist’s task.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “Hughes illustrates in the poem his enjoyment of painting.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The poem makes use of strong imagery and sharp contrast.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex attitudes toward nature and the artist’s task.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The speaker of the poem wants to emulate in the task of painting the stillness and peace he observes in the water lily, which has remained calm for centuries regardless of the size or type of disruption.”

· “Through the contrast of the warrior-like insects and the serene water lily, the speaker conveys an appreciation of the stillness of the water lily that transcends time and is unflappable amid distraction. It’s a stillness that exists in nature and is required for the task of creating art.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Collins conveys the narrator’s attitude through his use of literary techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This passage reminds us to use our time wisely.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “In this excerpt, Collins uses interrupting phrases to qualify or emphasize the speaker’s statements.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the narrator’s complex attitude toward the people he describes.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The narrator is disgusted by the idleness of the upper class that destroys the natural world and convinces them of the intellectual value of their destruction.”

· “The narrator appreciates the natural beauty of the world and perceives people’s scientific tinkering with it as a pointless effort to find meaning in their lives when they are bored. Collins conveys the sincerity behind the narrator’s attitude by employing a conversational tone and directly addressing the audience.”

Examples that do not earn this point:

· “In The Divine Comedy, Dante’s journey is an important element.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Obasan explores ideas about memories and how we understand our past.”

· “Voltaire’s novella Candide is a satire that explores optimism and hypocrisy.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of a physical journey in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how a physical journey contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Inman’s physical journey in Cold Mountain from the army hospital to reunite with Ada is fraught with peril, signifying how one’s deserting a cause he doesn’t believe in to follow his conscience and pursue love can require great moral strength.”

· “The pilgrimage in The Canterbury Tales offers the travelers an opportunity to share their stories and opinions, which exposes the folly and hypocrisy of people at every social rank in English society and the necessity of fellowship despite these failings.”

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Larkin uses literary techniques to convey the speaker’s attitude toward the places he describes.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The poem inspires readers to take greater appreciation for their surroundings.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The poem makes use of detailed description and alliteration to emphasize ideas.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex attitude toward the places he describes.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “While the speaker doesn’t condemn the more urban areas he travels through, he feels most comfortable near the isolated villages and beach where there are fewer human-made restrictions and life can happen organically or limitlessly.”

· “Larkin conveys the speaker’s preference for places of solitude over crowded areas by shifting away from concrete setting description in the urban areas to contemplative language that describes both the physical and mental experience of the isolated villages.”

· “Larkin uses literary techniques to convey the speaker’s attitude toward the places he describes.”

· “The poem inspires readers to take greater appreciation for their surroundings.”

Notes for this rubric row:

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on summary or description of a poem rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the poem contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the poem to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the poem contribute to its meaning
o.af:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the poem to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the poem.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Wide Sargasso Sea, a betrayal contributes to the meaning of the novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “The Awakening follows the life of Edna Pontellier as she develops unconventional views about her life as a wife and mother.”

· “Petry’s The Street tells the story of Lutie Johnson, her spirit, and her struggles.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of a betrayal in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how a betrayal contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The reason Iago’s betrayal of Othello is so tragic is because his preying upon Othello’s insecurities as an outsider leads Othello to betray himself.”

· “In ‘The Ballad of the Sad Café’ Cousin Lymon’s betrayal of Miss Amelia, destroys her livelihood and breaks her heart, all in an effort to impress Marvin Macy. However, the betrayal offers Lymon no protection from his suffering a similar fate in his one-sided infatuation with Marvin Macy.”

Restate the prompt

· “Austen uses techniques to characterize Catherine’s personality.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This passage celebrates the uniqueness of children.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This excerpt is complex because of Austen’s masterful use of sophisticated diction and vivid imagery.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex characterization of Catherine.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Austen presents Catherine as a lively child, whose seemingly ordinary qualities and lack of accomplishment do not prevent her from having an adventurous approach to life.”

· “In the passage, Catherine’s energy and independence establish her as more capable than her proficiency at schoolwork suggests. Austen conveys this through multiple contrasts and interrupting phrases which reflect her dynamic character.”

Restate the prompt

· “In To the Lighthouse, the portrayal of childhood contributes to the meaning of the novel.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Bless Me, Ultima is a bildungsroman set in New Mexico.”

· “The novel Jane Eyre includes themes of love and morality.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the portrayal of childhood or adolescence in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the portrayal of childhood or adolescence contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Adolescence is depicted through Holden’s insecurity and bitterness in The Catcher in the Rye as a time when teenagers can see the flaws of adulthood, can’t return to the innocence of childhood, and lack the maturity to reconcile the two.”

· “In Romeo and Juliet, Romeo and Juliet think independently from their families, yet their actions lack patience, revealing adolescence to be a mix of independence and inexperience that is challenging for both parents and adolescents themselves.”

Responses that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “While the narrator’s memories retain the innocence of childhood, her recollection of her locked diary and box of private things signify her burgeoning desire for both privacy and meaningful connection.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:

· Only restate the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Wise Blood, home continues to have an influence.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Ishiguro’s Never Let Me Go is a dystopian novel set in the 20th-century.”

· “Wilson’s The Piano Lesson explores the differing ideas of a brother and sister about what to do with a family piano.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the continuing influence of “home” on the character in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the continuing influence of “home” on the character contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Following Ashima’s move from India to the U.S. in The Namesake, she holds tightly to the values and traditions of home as a way to establish a sense of security in a foreign country that she might not have moved to except for the purpose of supporting her husband.”

· “In Brave New World, John’s values of love and personal connection, developed in his formative years at home on the Reservation, help him maintain his humanity within the dystopian totalitarian version of London, yet ultimately lead to his demise because his surroundings reject his values from home.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Emma circles around themes of romance and status.”

· “Oedipus’ speech at the beginning of Oedipus Rex, cursing the murderer of Laius and vowing to rid Thebes of the plague, illuminates the loyalty and hubris that ultimately brings about his downfall.”

o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Major Barbara, an illuminating scene conveys the larger meaning of the play.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Emma circles around themes of romance and status.”

· “Ellison’s Invisible Man explores the narrator’s sense of individuality and invisibility in society.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the “illuminating” episode in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the “illuminating” episode contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Dimmesdale’s revealing the scarlet letter he marked on his chest and his subsequent death not only emphasize the strength of Hester to live honestly in ostracism, but also illuminate the necessity to live authentically, lest one’s shame cause self-destruction.”

· “Oedipus’ speech at the beginning of Oedipus Rex, cursing the murderer of Laius and vowing to rid Thebes of the plague, illuminates the loyalty and hubris that ultimately brings about his downfall.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:

o.af:

o.d:

o.af:

o.d:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Roth’s American Pastoral, Swede’s character is affected by a 1960s political and social issue.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “The play Angels in America explores the concept of community.”

· “Julius Caesar highlights the distinction and blurriness of personal feelings and public appearances.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of how a political or social issue affects either character or plot development in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how a political or social issue affects either character or plot development and contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Allende’s The House of the Spirits, the military coup that results in Esteban’s loss of political status and great suffering for his family, cracks open Esteban’s stubborn and unsympathetic nature, driving home Allende’s point that even the most headstrong and hard-hearted can become more compassionate, but it may take great personal and political strife.”

· “Morrison’s The Bluest Eye challenges the audience to consider how Pecola’s madness is the consequence of racism and sexism working in concert and left unchecked by society.”

· “Miller critiques in Death of a Salesman the American Dream as attainable for all through hard work. Despite Willy’s willingness to work hard, he is unable to achieve financial security, which triggers his psychological deterioration. This suggests that the American Dream requires perhaps a confluence of skills, qualities, and opportunities that are only available to some, not all.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In her poem ‘The Myth of Music,’ Harper establishes a connection between music and family memories.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “‘The Myth of Music’ reveals how people often appreciate what they have in hindsight.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The poet illustrates her meaning through the use of metaphors and imagery.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the relationship between music and the speaker’s complex memories of her family.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Harper’s use of figurative language and vivid diction establish music as a core aspect of the speaker’s identity because it connects her to the love and memories of her parents, establishing a unique sense of her family and its legacy.”

· “The speaker’s formative understanding of her family was shaped in the context of the music her father loved, music that as an adult reminds her of what is timeless—their love—and what is finite—their time together.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:

Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The interplay between Mr. Pickle’s and Mr. Gauntlet’s emotions and social propriety is complex.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “The author illustrates how both Godfrey and Mr. Pickle are connected to Emilia.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This excerpt focuses the reader’s attention on the interaction between Mr. Pickle and Gauntlet through dialogue and description.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex interplay between emotions and social propriety in the passage.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Godfrey and Peregrine, through their love for Emilia and perhaps an even greater love for their reputations, attempt to resolve their anger at each other by conforming to social norms that are violent in either word or action.”

· “Smollett reveals through this passage that social propriety can exacerbate conflict if people, like Pickle and Gauntlet, do not confront their own emotions before challenging others, as such is the case in The Adventures of Peregrine Pickle.”

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

FT557834-22_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In John Gardner’s novel Grendel, the protagonist, Grendel, is a monstrous creature whose unusual origins affect him and his relationships with others.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “‘The Odyssey’ is an epic poem whose structure is an example of ‘the hero’s journey.’”

· “Viola in Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night is an interesting character who finds herself in many humorous moments.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of how these unusual or mysterious origins have a complex effect on the character or the character’s relationships in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how these unusual or mysterious origins and their complex effect on the character or the character’s relationships contribute to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Brave New World, John’s origins as someone who was born naturally on the Reservation make him a figure of both fascination and contempt among those who live in the World State and were reproductively engineered.”

· “Jay Gatsby’s mysterious origins create intrigue among the upper class and allow him to penetrate the upper echelons of society, however, the secrecy around his true origins (not to mention the prevalent classism at the time) prevent him from attaining any authentic relationships with them.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the selected work.
o.af:

Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response must address the interpretation of the selected work as a whole.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The speaker uses questions to reveal her thoughts about marriage.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The poem’s structure, imagery, and tone present the speaker’s desire to travel.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The wife in the poem discusses her marriage through metaphors and similes.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex thoughts about her marriage.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Although the speaker in ‘The Wife Speaks’ will accept a peaceful, albeit uneventful, relationship with her husband as they continue grow older, she longs to bring back the love and passion of their youth, no matter how chaotic.”

· “Stoddard’s usage of burning imagery and an exciting tone convey the poet’s desire to revive her marriage with her husband and experience a future worth dying for.”

· “In her poem ‘The Wife Speaks’ Stoddard utilizes imagery and reflective tones to demonstrate her ideas on marriage. She eloquently poses the question: do we settle for comfortable, or strive for something more?”

Responses that earn this point:

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Stoddard’s usage of burning imagery and an exciting tone convey the poet’s desire to revive her marriage with her husband and experience a future worth dying for.”

· “In her poem ‘The Wife Speaks’ Stoddard utilizes imagery and reflective tones to demonstrate her ideas on marriage. She eloquently poses the question: do we settle for comfortable, or strive for something more?”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Kincaid’s narrator makes adept use of literary devices when discuss the complexity of her new situation.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “The narrator in Kincaid’s novel demonstrates the importance of home and belonging.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “Kincaid uses very detailed description of places and contrasting of those places to develop the narrator’s experience.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complexity of the narrator’s new situation.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Kincaid, through the use of imagery, em dashes, and repetition revealed her complex dilemma of wanting to go home or staying in a newer environment.”

· “In 1990, Jamaica Kincaid’s novel Lucy, depicts this life change and the narrator’s feelings. Kincaid uses repetition of phrases, diction that illicits pathos, and a mood of uncertainty and questioning to show how the narrator feels unsure and worried about moving from her hometown and how, despite a chance to restart her life, she still wants to go back.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Catch-22, Yossarian makes a judgment that something else is more important than his fear during the war. This shows his dreams, goals, and values.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Throughout the novel, [Macbeth] has a powerful promise to his advantage and the reader is able to notice how well-rooted his values are and has a major character change that makes him unrecognizable at the end of the novel.”

· “This play [‘A Doll’s House’] the dynamic of a married couple and also highlighted the struggles and challenges that everyday people have in their household that are usually never represented in media during that time period.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of how the complexity of the character’s judgment reveals the character’s dreams, goals, or values in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the complexity of the character’s judgment reveals the character’s dreams, goals, or values and contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Victor Frankenstein is not often seen as a noble character, as most who overcome fear are. He allowed many people to die at the hands of his creation before attempting to seek it out. However, in Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein, Victor Frankenstein eventually overcomes the fear of his own creation in order to protect the rest of humankind and seek revenge.”

· “Despite societal pressures and the fear that this ‘sivilization’ imposes on Huckleberry Finn, the main character’s growth and realization of the world around him also leads to a growth in noble courage—the courage to defy society and its obsolete moral codes and follow the true compass of morality that is in all of our hearts—our conscience.”

· “In [Sophocles’] play Antigone, Antigone herself ignores the danger and her own fear of being severely punished to rightfully bury her brother. Her actions reveal how much family means to her, so much that she is willing to risk her life for it…and proves that love for family provides courage and strength in the most trying of times.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the selected work.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Catch-22, Yossarian makes a judgment that something else is more important than his fear during the war. This shows his dreams, goals, and values.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “Throughout the novel, [Macbeth] has a powerful promise to his advantage and the reader is able to notice how well-rooted his values are and has a major character change that makes him unrecognizable at the end of the novel.”

· “This play [‘A Doll’s House’] the dynamic of a married couple and also highlighted the struggles and challenges that everyday people have in their household that are usually never represented in media during that time period.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of how the complexity of the character’s judgment reveals the character’s dreams, goals, or values in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the complexity of the character’s judgment reveals the character’s dreams, goals, or values and contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Victor Frankenstein is not often seen as a noble character, as most who overcome fear are. He allowed many people to die at the hands of his creation before attempting to seek it out. However, in Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein, Victor Frankenstein eventually overcomes the fear of his own creation in order to protect the rest of humankind and seek revenge.”

· “Despite societal pressures and the fear that this ‘sivilization’ imposes on Huckleberry Finn, the main character’s growth and realization of the world around him also leads to a growth in noble courage—the courage to defy society and its obsolete moral codes and follow the true compass of morality that is in all of our hearts—our conscience.”

· “In [Sophocles’] play Antigone, Antigone herself ignores the danger and her own fear of being severely punished to rightfully bury her brother. Her actions reveal how much family means to her, so much that she is willing to risk her life for it…and proves that love for family provides courage and strength in the most trying of times.”

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response must address the interpretation of the selected work as a whole.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the poem must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The author uses the literary techniques of syntax, diction, and figurative language in the poem ‘Plants.’”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “Olive Senior has a distinct way of writing poems. Seniors structure of [her] poems are not commonly seen in the poetry world and [her] diction is straight forward.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “In Olive Senior’s poem ‘Plants’ [she] compares plants to many life situations among telling the story about what plants do.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex relationships among the speaker, the implied audience, and plant life.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “By demonstrating many similarities between plants and humans, the speaker demonstrates the deception that is present in everyday life. By using the literary techniques of syntax, diction, and figurative language the poet intends to connect humans with nature.”

· “The speaker believes that the current complex relationship between humans and plants should be changed to prevent plant life from dominating humans.”

· “One such poet is Olive Senior, who expresses [her] view of plant life as toxic in [her] poem ‘Plants.’”

· “Hawthorne illustrates the importance of wealth and beauty.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The narrator feels as though Zenobia may not be entirely authentic.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “There are many novels and plays in which something important is gifted to a character.”

· “A novel that has a character with a literal of figurative gift was the main character in Frankenstein. He was given a gift that was a burden, but also an advantage and a problem.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “In the story of ‘The Tempest’ by Shakespeare there is a wizard who was casted away with his infant daughter to an inhibited island for years. This wizard has special powers, with them he was able to free someone from a spell and make them a servant.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex nature of a gift in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the complex nature of a gift contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Ian McEwan’s Atonement, Briony has the gift of prolific writing at a young age, but when she begins to attempt to solve her own problems through writing happy endings, McEwan shows the reader that Briony’s attempt to play God is not only futile but also destructive.”

· “Elizabeth’s frustration at the way she is stereotyped demonstrates that—for women trapped in strictly-enforced gender roles—traditional beauty is a double-edged sword.”

· “Although the ‘gift’ of metaphorical invisibility, as shown through the novel’s varied characters, can be utilized to (arguably) bolster freedom, - freedom in terms of anonymity – Ellison, through the ‘Invisible Man’s’ reflections, asserts that such invisibility is immensely impairing, as it stubbornly prevents its victims from making an impact on society as they’re imprisoned in oppressive expectations. Ellison ultimately implies that an acceptance of one’s invisibility, rather than a firm ideology on how to relieve it, is the path to self-understanding.”

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

FT567785-22_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

FT584698-22_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the poem must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In Dunbar’s poem, he contemplates his existence and portrays it as complex through literary elements.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The poem focuses on the power of nature in life.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “In ‘The Mystery’ Dunbar writes about a higher power and death and his purpose.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex nature of the speaker’s existence and his conclusions about it.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Dunbar explores the nature of his existence—and consequently, of man—in a state of eternal loops. Like the ouroboros, he circles himself forever without finding the end. He seems to accept this, though, as the nature of being is a ‘secret’ he seeks, perhaps not meant to be discovered by him as he stands alone.”

· “In the poem, ‘The Mystery,’ Paul Laurence Dunbar explores the directionless nature of life, characterizing it as a lonely journey dictated by fate. Dunbar illustrates this journey by using dramatic imagery and metaphoric representations to expound on his ignorance and lack of control regarding the path he will take and the purpose he strives toward.”

· “Eventually, the speaker arrives to a conclusion about the nature of his existence that it is unpredictable and difficult to understand, for his pathway is not guided and he is not given answers to his questions.”

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the poem.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on summary or description of a poem rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the poem contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the poem to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the poem contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the poem to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the poem.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “C. E. Morgan’s ‘All the Living’ conveys a story about a young girl journey moving away from her family, Morgan uses literary elements to depict Aloma’s experiences.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “Aloma prefers dissonance to harmony in life.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “[The novel ‘All the Living’] is about a girl name Aloma who has to go to a new school because her uncle and aunt couldn’t handle her anymore…In the novel ‘All the Living’ uses a simile and imagery to reveal how Aloma was to her new environment.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Aloma’s complex responses to her changing environment.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In C. E. Morgan’s novel, All the living, Aloma’s experience moving away from her extended family and being exposed to a new environment provides her with complex emotions that ultimately lead to a self-realization. Morgan’s descriptions of Aloma’s life with her aunt and uncle convey the life of mediocracy and restrained circumstance that Aloma hopes to escape.”

· “Aloma’s experience of isolation at the school, served to amplify her desire to be free to be where she wants to be, and who she wants to be.”

· “Though at home and at school, she is constantly restricted both literally and figuratively by the mountains that surround her, she seeks a life where the sun is free to shine directly at her, where she is unconstrained and can be ‘someone other than the person [she was] born to be.’”

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In the novel ‘A Clockwork Orange’ there is a blending of laughter and suffering.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “The satire of Brave New World shows Huxley’s beliefs about society.”

· “Macbeth is a play about a thane who wants to be king and will do anything, even murder, to get it.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex effect of the interaction of humor and suffering in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how the complex effect of the interaction of humor and suffering contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the novel ‘One Flew Over the Cuckoo’s Nest,’ the author tells the story of an escalating conflict between a ward nurse and a new Patient. Yet nurse Ratched and McMurphy’s story is far more than this, it is a story of perseverance. It is also the story of recovery, and that recovery is mirrored through the opposition of laughter and harsh control under nurse Ratched’s mechanical grip.”

· “Blending humor and suffering to convey the issues of courting and social norms Austen satirizes her society.”

· “The dipiction of these two edges of beauty further that happiness cannot be attained without suffering. Both Jim and Huck learn that there are times for laughter and times for anguish in life to achieve a dream.”

· “The Fool acts as a comedic relief and humourously portrays King Lear’s stupidity and foreshadows his suffering. This is key in the meaning of the play because it emphasizes the importance of rewarding those who are deserving rather than those who are flattering.”

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

· Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

o.d: The response demonstrates sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.

By this point in the course, as they begin writing full essays, students may understand enough about developing and expressing literary arguments to be able to earn the point in this row. By the end of Unit 2, students should have a fundamental understanding of how to approach a literary analysis. This partial task is designed to offer an opportunity to practice performing such analysis in writing. The theses students write at this point in the course may not be as well developed as those expected for the summative exam; therefore, for this item students may earn the point in this row for any relevant thesis that is clearly stated and supported by evidence.

In Unit 2, students continue to develop the skills involved in making and supporting defensible theses. In this unit, students explore how figurative language such as simile and metaphor functions in a text to create meaning through comparisons; this preparation should be useful to students as they approach this task. At this point in the course, students are still developing the skills involved in explaining the relationships between evidence and thesis; thus, students may only earn up to 2 points in this row. In some cases, student responses may exceed the criteria for these 2 points on this formative assessment. Students will be able to earn up to 4 points in this row in later units and on the summative AP Exam.

By this point, students should be ready to begin building the skills involved in developing commentary that connects evidence and reasoning. Whereas earlier units focus on how character is conveyed through textual detail, in Unit 3, students examine how those textual details can contribute to a reader’s interpretation of a character; this preparation should be useful to students as they approach this task. This passage features a complex interaction between two characters, and the interaction offers an abundance of details illustrating a character’s complex motivations. At this point in the course, students are likely still developing the skills involved in explaining the relationships between evidence and thesis; thus, students may only earn up to 2 points in this row. In some cases, student responses may exceed the criteria for these 2 points on this formative assessment. Students will be able to earn up to 4 points in this row in later units and on the summative AP Exam.

This poem employs a number of contrasts. Although the concept of contrasts in texts was introduced in earlier units, it is revisited in Unit 6 in a more sophisticated way: Unit 6 focuses on helping students understand how contrasts can introduce nuance, ambiguity, or contradiction that makes texts more complex. This preparation should be useful to students as they approach this passage and task. By this point in the course, students should be gaining familiarity with the skills required for developing commentary that connects evidence and reasoning. However, they are not expected to be entirely consistent in their explanations of the relationships between evidence and thesis; thus, students may only earn up to 3 points in this row for this unit. In some cases, student responses may exceed the criteria for these 3 points on this formative assessment. Students will be able to earn up to 4 points in this row in later units and on the summative AP Exam.

In Unit 7, students explore how interactions between and among characters contribute to characterization; this preparation should be useful to students as they approach this task. Note the complexity of the relationship between the two characters in this passage, and how it is exhibited in their interactions as well as in the main character’s reflections. While earlier units addressed conflict and connection among characters, in this unit students have been introduced to more nuanced analysis of how the details of interactions between characters can be revealing. By this point in the course, students should be gaining confidence in deploying the skills involved in developing commentary that connects evidence and reasoning. As such, students may earn up to 4 points in this row as they would on the summative (May) AP exam.

At this point in the course, students are likely still developing the skills involved in explaining the relationships among evidence, reasoning, and claims; thus, students may only earn up to 2 points in this row. Students will be able to earn up to 4 points in this row when they write full essays in later units. Remember that for the exam, there is no canon of expected texts, nor are students rewarded or penalized for choosing texts included on the question’s accompanying list.
