Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The author uses a variety of literary techniques to show the various emotions a lady feels when she tries to burn a bunch of letters from an old boyfriend.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “Cheating on a spouse can lead to a wide range of emotions, such as those experienced by the woman in the short story.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The short story mentions the house the woman is living in, describes the weather conditions, and depicts the woman’s complex state of mind as she sets out to burn her lover’s letters.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the woman’s complex emotions regarding her letters.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “By using body imagery, especially images of the woman’s hands and arms in motion in the act of destroying the letters, the author shows both the woman’s desire to destroy the letters and her mounting anguish and regret at the prospect of losing her connection with her former lover.”

· “The author conveys the woman’s anxiety through an ingenious narrative technique: starting with a detached, third-person perspective, the author moves readers directly into the mind and emotions of the woman as she begins destroying the letters, a technique underscored by the use of exclamation points and hyperbolic diction. Readers feel the woman’s anguish—as well as her passion for the relationship she is attempting to leave behind—as if it were their own.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the passage.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The author uses a variety of literary techniques to show the various emotions a lady feels when she tries to burn a bunch of letters from an old boyfriend.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “Cheating on a spouse can lead to a wide range of emotions, such as those experienced by the woman in the short story.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The short story mentions the house the woman is living in, describes the weather conditions, and depicts the woman’s complex state of mind as she sets out to burn her lover’s letters.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the woman’s complex emotions regarding her letters.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “By using body imagery, especially images of the woman’s hands and arms in motion in the act of destroying the letters, the author shows both the woman’s desire to destroy the letters and her mounting anguish and regret at the prospect of losing her connection with her former lover.”

· “The author conveys the woman’s anxiety through an ingenious narrative technique: starting with a detached, third-person perspective, the author moves readers directly into the mind and emotions of the woman as she begins destroying the letters, a technique underscored by the use of exclamation points and hyperbolic diction. Readers feel the woman’s anguish—as well as her passion for the relationship she is attempting to leave behind—as if it were their own.”

VR217087_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the passage.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the passage contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the passage contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

Restate the prompt

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The author uses contrast, juxtaposition and vivid language to show Mrs. Pritchett’s complex reaction.”

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The author establishes a series of expectations as Mrs. Pritchett imagines her day ahead and then systematically upends those expectations to show that her attempts to keep her life ‘...small and contained, filled with bourgeois pleasures...’ have limited her ability to be happy.”

While the narrator holds her mother’s sophistication in high regard, she also realizes how her mother’s aloof nature denies her the excitement and comfort she craves as a child.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the narrator’s complex understanding of her mother.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The author uses a combination of realistic description and inventive figurative language to capture how the young narrator feels both bitter resentment and deep awe toward her mother.”

· “By consistently contrasting images of the mother’s interactions in public with images of her interactions with the narrator, the author conveys the young narrator’s contradictory feelings toward her mother. While the narrator holds her mother’s sophistication in high regard, she also realizes how her mother’s aloof nature denies her the excitement and comfort she craves as a child.”

VR217090_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the passage.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the passage contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the passage contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

VR217090_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The author masterfully uses a variety of literary techniques to demonstrate Lee’s complex feelings about her new life.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “The reading passage makes a powerful statement about how one’s environment and sense of community or loneliness may be linked.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The author employs a combination of detailed description and dialogue to orient the reader in Lee’s new environment.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Lee’s complex feelings about her new life.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Throughout the passage, the author uses the contrasting imagery of light and darkness to reflect Lee’s longing for expression and connection in the face of loneliness and detachment.”

· “The character Lee, in her previous life as a model, was the object of the camera’s focus. In this passage, the author uses Lee’s fumbling attempts to use the camera to represent her lack of meaningful connection in her new life as an aspiring artist.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The author illustrates Moose’s complex mindset through the use of several literary techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “The excerpt gives us a glimpse into the complex relationships that often exist between college faculty members.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The author uses a third person point of view that is limited to Moose to present his thoughts.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the author’s portrayal of Moose’s complex state of mind.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The description of Moose’s actions and his inner dialogue reveal him to have an unconventional and persistent nature that is valued by his students, but not his colleagues, rendering him anxious and suspicious.”

· “In this excerpt, the author uses vivid description of Moose’s walk as a symbolic journey from a pretentious and confident mindset (he walks where he believes there should be a sidewalk) to a mindset that is more self-conscious and unnerved when he encounters his less-than-friendly colleagues. This reflects his discomfort with the tension between his unique perspective the students enjoy and his colleagues do not.”

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The author conveys Orvil’s complex reaction to his first dance contest.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “In this passage, the author reveals the importance of finding a way to connect to your cultural heritage.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The author uses many details to convey the colorful sights and sounds of the scene as the men get ready to perform their dance.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Orvil’s complex reaction to his situation.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The author illustrates how Orvil’s participation in his first powwow serves to heighten his feelings of being an outsider in the culture he wants to connect with and simultaneously serves to strengthen his connection with that culture.”

· “The writer employs vivid detail, communicated through short, punchy sentences and repetition to mimic the rhythm of the traditional Native American dancing as well as the trance-like mindset Orvil knows he must enter in order to dance successfully.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In a 1975 novel, a writer portrays a boy from the 1900’s perspective on change with complex literary elements and techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “The passage illustrates how important a relationship with a grandparent can be for a child.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The writer connects the boy’s feelings about growing up to magic.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the boy’s complex perspective on change.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “By linking the boy’s reaction to growing up to his fascination with his grandfather’s stories of transformation, the author shows that the boy views change as a mystery to be explored.”

· “In the passage, the writer uses descriptions of the boy’s behavior to illustrate what he thinks about getting older. By providing the boy’s responses to things like his grandfather’s stories and his own observations alongside his mother’s feelings that he is ‘a strange child,’ the writer communicates that the boy’s perspective on change is out of the ordinary.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

o.d:

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.af:

o.d:

o.af:

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The writer uses literary techniques to portray Jerónimo Portal’s complex relationship with the plaza where he sits every day.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “In this passage, we see how change is an unavoidable part of life.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The author uses descriptions of the buildings in the plaza to depict Jerónimo Portal’s surroundings.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex relationship between Jerónimo Portal and the plaza.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Jerónimo Portal is a man used to an older way of life. The author uses detailed descriptions of his memories of how the plaza looked long ago and how it looks now to depict how he has had to deal with change in his own life.”

· “The use of vivid details to describe the plaza mixed with Jerónimo Portal’s point of view create the impression that he is a man trying to hold onto a small space in a present time to which he feels unconnected.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The author effectively employs literary elements to show Miranda’s complex reaction to watching her great-aunt and her grandmother.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “The author reveals how children often believe their elders were never young themselves.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The author uses dialogue and descriptions to show the personalities of the two older women.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Miranda’s complex reaction as she observes the two older women.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Through the effective use of description and dialogue, the writer reveals that Miranda is surprised to notice for the first time that her Great Aunt Eliza and Grandmother are very different from how she had previously perceived them, and she is now embarrassed by their behavior which seems unrefined.”

· “By contrasting the childish interaction that Miranda observes between her great-aunt and grandmother with Miranda’s usual perception of them as authority figures, the author creates a situation in which Miranda begins to question the trappings of adulthood and faces an uncomfortable glimpse into her own future.”

· “Just as spring turns to summer turns to autumn, so Dorinda’s thinking in this passage follows a similar path from naivete to maturity.”

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “By describing how Dorinda won Jason’s affections and her realization that in love ‘honesty is at best a questionable policy,’ the writer lays the foundation for why Dorinda begins to doubt Jason’s happiness in their engagement.”

· “Just as spring turns to summer turns to autumn, so Dorinda’s thinking in this passage follows a similar path from naivete to maturity.”

VR217097_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the passage.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the passage contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the passage contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

VR217097_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought and/or develops a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The author uses literary elements to show Mrs. Baroda’s response to her encounter with Gouvernail.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “In this passage, the author addresses a common problem in relationships: what happens when one partner has an issue with the other’s friend?”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The writer lets us see Mrs. Baroda’s thoughts and gives a description of her actual behavior.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Mrs. Baroda’s complex response to her encounter with Gouvernail.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The author’s use of an omniscient narrator allows the reader to contrast Mrs. Baroda’s outward behavior towards Gouvernail—which on the surface seems cold--but her interior response to him is warm.”

· “Mrs. Baroda, a married woman, is torn between the restrictions of respectability and her own desires. This conflict is shown through the writer’s description of Mrs. Baroda’s thoughts about Gouvernail, her actions towards him, the repetition of the words ‘a respectable woman,’ and her conversation with her husband at the end of the passage.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The author uses literary techniques to reveal Wash’s feelings about encountering another person at his painting spot.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “Through this passage, the writer reveals that appearances aren’t always what they seem.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The detailed description of the beach is helpful in visualizing the setting where Wash likes to paint.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Wash’s complex response to encountering another person at the beach.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Wash’s suspicion of the other person at the beach is normal and understandable given his escape from slavery; however, his realization that this other person is an artist and that he shouldn’t restrict his freedom is important and reveals the depths of his character and life experience.”

· “The author reveals through vivid details and inner dialogue how Wash moves through feelings of hesitation, annoyance, anger, and acceptance in response to the fellow artist because of his appreciation for freedom and the common link of humanity.”

Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

VR217101_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The literary elements and techniques in this passage convey Dina’s complex response to the library and the recital hall.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “The passage shows that you may learn more about the world by visiting new places.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The passage is split up into two scenes: one at the library and one at the recital hall.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Dina’s complex response to these places.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Through Dina’s reflection on the past and her focus on the present, the author reveals the complex feelings the library and recital hall inspire in her with regard to her sense of isolation and curiosity.”

· “Dina’s visits to the library and the recital hall reveal her internal struggle; even as she becomes a student of the world around her, she still feels like an imposter.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the passage.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The literary elements and techniques in this passage convey Dina’s complex response to the library and the recital hall.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “The passage shows that you may learn more about the world by visiting new places.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The passage is split up into two scenes: one at the library and one at the recital hall.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Dina’s complex response to these places.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Through Dina’s reflection on the past and her focus on the present, the author reveals the complex feelings the library and recital hall inspire in her with regard to her sense of isolation and curiosity.”

· “Dina’s visits to the library and the recital hall reveal her internal struggle; even as she becomes a student of the world around her, she still feels like an imposter.”

VR217101_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the passage.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the passage contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the passage contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the passage must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

o.d:
The response demonstrates at least one of the following:

· There is no defensible thesis.

· The intended thesis only restates the prompt.

· The intended thesis provides a summary of the issue with no apparent or coherent claim.

· There is a thesis, but it does not respond to the prompt.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The author portrays Hortense’s arrival in England using a variety of literary techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “Relocating to a new country is difficult for anyone, but it is especially hard for someone doing so alone.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “In this passage, Hortense arrives in England and finds that Gilbert has neglected to meet her as expected.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Hortense’s complex responses to this experience.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Hortense’s loneliness grows more profound as she watches fellow new arrivals being greeted by friends and family while she waits for Gilbert.”

· “Through the use of vivid sensory detail and dialogue, Levy paints a frantic scene – one that reflects Hortense’s sense of uncertainty and confusion upon her arrival in England.”

· “In this excerpt, Hortense depicts a contrast between her quiet disappointment and the boisterous actions of those around her. This technique portrays the stark difference between how Hortense expected to react upon her arrival and how she reacts now that those expectations have been dashed.”

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the poem must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Butler E. Brewton uses several literary elements and techniques to communicate a complex attitude toward the past and future.”

· “In the poem ‘Rafters,’ we are presented with a speaker who has a complex relationship with both his past and his future.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The 1995 poem ‘Rafters’ portrays a common American experience where young people leave rural areas and move to urban ones.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “The speaker first describes the old barn on the farm where he grew up, which reminds him of having left his father’s farm to move to the city. But ultimately he moves back to his family farm.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex attitude toward the past and future.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In his poem 'Rafters,’ Brewton develops the speaker’s initially unsettled attitude toward his past into a renewed sense of purpose as he contemplates his future.”

· “The poem juxtaposes the farm that represents the speaker’s past with the city, which represents his present (and what he would have once argued as his future). He feels a profound sense of loss when he reflects on his experiences in both settings.”

· “Brewton employs the literary elements of vivid imagery and interior thought to reveal how the narrator has come full circle, deciding that returning to his childhood home and taking up his father’s old plow is the best course for his future.”

· Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In ‘Seventeen Syllables,’ Hisaye Yamamoto employs various elements and techniques to convey the complex reaction that Rosie has to her mother’s career as a poet.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This excerpt from a short story illustrates the communication gap that exists between many children and their parents.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The writer uses the third person limited point of view when writing this story so the reader can know what Rosie is thinking.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Rosie’s complex response to this period in her mother’s life.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Yamamoto uses the language barrier between Rosie and her mother to symbolize Rosie’s inability to connect with her mother’s new interest in poetry.”

· “In ‘Seventeen Syllables,’ Hisaye Yamamoto presents the growing distance between Rosie and her mother by emphasizing Rosie’s puzzled and irritated attitude towards her mother’s life as a poet.”

· “In her short story ‘Seventeen Syllables,’ Hisaye Yamamoto provides descriptions of Rosie's family life before and after her mother began writing poetry to emphasize Rosie's increasing feelings of alienation within her household.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “This excerpt from a short story illustrates the communication gap that exists between many children and their parents.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “The writer uses the third person limited point of view when writing this story so the reader can know what Rosie is thinking.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of Rosie’s complex response to this period in her mother’s life.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Yamamoto uses the language barrier between Rosie and her mother to symbolize Rosie’s inability to connect with her mother’s new interest in poetry.”

· “In ‘Seventeen Syllables,’ Hisaye Yamamoto presents the growing distance between Rosie and her mother by emphasizing Rosie’s puzzled and irritated attitude towards her mother’s life as a poet.”

· “In her short story ‘Seventeen Syllables,’ Hisaye Yamamoto provides descriptions of Rosie's family life before and after her mother began writing poetry to emphasize Rosie's increasing feelings of alienation within her household.”

VR597002_rubric_category_1.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

· To earn the fourth point in this row, the response may observe multiple instances of the same literary element or technique if each instance further contributes to the meaning of the passage.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a passage rather than specific details or techniques.

· Mention literary elements, devices, or techniques with little or no explanation.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how at least one literary element or technique in the passage contributes to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates all of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]

· Explains how multiple literary elements or techniques in the passage contribute to its meaning
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the passage to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

VR597002_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought nor develop a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Disappointment occurs when something fails to meet our hopes or expectations. Since the beginning of time, people have been disappointed by events, ideas, objects, and even other people.”

· “How we react to the disappointments we experience can have a major impact on our lives. Many works of literature, such as The Joy Luck Club, depict how characters react to being disappointed.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “In Hemingway's novel The Sun Also Rises, Jake Barnes's association with Lady Brett Ashley ultimately creates tension within their circle of friends.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of a character’s response to disappointment in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how a character’s response to disappointment contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In Great Expectations, Pip's disappointment over Estella’s refusal to return his passion leads to a frustrating pursuit of love that nevertheless allows him to recognize that there are other more enduring and meaningful relationships in his life.”

· “James Gatz’s transformation into the charismatic millionaire Jay Gatsby is the direct result of his disappointment over losing Daisy Buchanan. Unfortunately, his attempt to win her back results in even greater disappointments for both himself and those around him.”

· “Lear is disappointed by Cordelia’s refusal to flatter him, but it takes the true disappointment of Goneril and Regan revealing themselves as greedy and cruel for Lear to realize Cordelia is the only one of his daughters who truly loves him.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

· Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “The poet develops the complex associations with shaving through the use of several literary techniques.”

· “In his poem ‘Shaving,’ published in 1998, Richard Blanco presents a speaker that writes about the act of shaving and his complex relationship with it.”

Do not relate to the prompt

· “The loss of a parent is a difficult one, something that many people have to deal with as they get older.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

· “Blanco’s poem is made up of three stanzas that talk about shaving. He uses figurative language to convey many of his ideas.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the speaker’s complex associations with the ritual of shaving.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “In the 1998 poem ‘Shaving,’ Richard Blanco employs the literary technique of stream of consciousness to show how the simple act of shaving inspires complex associations with the father he barely knew.”

· “The poem links the speaker’s daily ritual of shaving new growth to the cycles of regeneration in nature and then ultimately to his father, whom he starts to see reborn in himself.”

· “Blanco uses vivid imagery and the presentation of the narrator’s thoughts to reveal how the act of shaving connects the narrator to his father, who seems to have died young, which then reminds the narrator of his own mortality.”

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “In this excerpt, the author depicts the community as complex through the use of various literary elements and techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

· “In many communities, people react in different ways to strange events.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

· “This passage employs magic realism to illustrate its point.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex characterization of the community.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “The community in this passage is characterized by fear, practicality, and reverence for the unknown.”

· “While the community collectively considers the appearance of the octopus to be significant—despite being uncertain of its meaning—the mother of Thomas personally sees it as a specific response to the birth of her son.”

· “Through the use of an unusual plot event and the characters’ responses to the octopus, the author exposes fault lines within the community that are not otherwise visible.”

· Explain how the writer’s use of multiple literary techniques contributes to the student’s interpretation of the passage.

VR598475_rubric_category_2.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought nor develop a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

· Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the passage could be said to…”).

· Make a single statement about how an interpretation of the passage comments on something thematic without consistently maintaining that thematic interpretation.

· Oversimplify complexities in the passage.

· Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the passage.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the passage.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

VR598476_rubric_category_0.s:
Select a point value to view scoring criteria, decision rules, and scoring notes, and to score the response.

Notes for this rubric row:

· The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

· The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

· For a thesis to be defensible, the selected work must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that offers a defensible claim about a character’s response to any type of hierarchical structure in the selected work may earn the point; any reasonable student interpretation of the terms “hierarchical structure” or “hierarchy” is acceptable.

· The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

· A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

· Only restate the prompt.

· Make a generalized comment about the selected work that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

· “Hierarchical structures are a major part of society. In literature, characters can be seen either accepting or rejecting economic, political, and familial hierarchies among others.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

· “In The Chrysalids by John Wyndham, David and the other telepaths hide their mutation from the rest of Waknuk, which is not an easy thing to do.”

· “People establish hierarchies because they believe they help keep order. Going against a hierarchy is very difficult. Many works of literature have characters that suffer the consequences of doing this.”

Responses that earn this point:

· Provide a defensible interpretation of how a character responds to a hierarchy in the selected work.

OR

· Make a claim about how a character’s response to a hierarchy contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

· “Offred’s development as a character in The Handmaid’s Tale is shaped by her quiet rebellion against a government hierarchy that enforces her assigned role as a Handmaid.”

· “In S.E. Hinton’s The Outsiders, Ponyboy and Cherry’s violation of the strict hierarchy of Greasers versus Socs causes several characters to question their loyalty to these groups and brings tragedy to those who try to uphold these rules.”

· “Hurston shows how the expectations put on Janie Crawford by her grandmother and her first two husbands are meant to uphold gender-based hierarchies in society and the family. After Janie revolts against these hierarchies and runs away with Tea Cake, she is able to become independent.”

o.d: The response responds to the prompt with a thesis that presents a defensible interpretation of the selected work.

Notes for this rubric row:

· Writing that suffers from grammatical and/or mechanical errors that interfere with communication cannot earn the fourth point in this row.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

· Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

· May be just opinion with no textual references or references that are irrelevant.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides evidence that is mostly general [EVIDENCE]

· Summarizes the evidence but does not explain how the evidence supports the student’s argument [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 1 point:

· Tend to focus on overarching narrative developments or description of a selected work rather than specific details.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides some specific, relevant evidence [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence relates to the student’s argument, but no line of reasoning is established, or the line of reasoning is faulty [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 2 points:

· Consist of a mix of specific evidence and broad generalities.

· May contain some simplistic, inaccurate, or repetitive explanations that don’t strengthen the argument.

· May make one point well but either do not make multiple supporting claims or do not adequately support more than one claim.

· Do not explain the connections or progression between the student’s claims, so a line of reasoning is not clearly established.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Explains how some of the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 3 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific words and details from the selected work to build an interpretation.

· Organize an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims.

· Commentary may fail to integrate some evidence or fail to support a key claim.

o.d:
The response demonstrates both of the following:

· Provides specific evidence to support all claims in a line of reasoning [EVIDENCE]

· Consistently explains how the evidence supports a line of reasoning [COMMENTARY]
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 4 points:

· Uniformly offer evidence to support claims.

· Focus on the importance of specific details from the selected works to build an interpretation.

· Organize and support an argument as a line of reasoning composed of multiple supporting claims, each with adequate evidence that is clearly explained.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Only restate the prompt.

  • Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

  • Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

  • “The poet employs multiple literary techniques to show how the speaker considers why waterfowl leave when humans arrive and to make a comparison between them.”

  • “A complex comparison between people and waterfowl is highlighted in the provided poem.”

Do not relate to the prompt

  • “Humans relate to the natural world and the animals in it in a way that is not always kind.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

  • “In this poem, the speaker asks questions of the waterfowl.”

Responses that earn this point:

  • Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex comparison between the waterfowl and humans.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

  • “The speaker compares waterfowl and humans to show how despite the fact that humans have more power, the waterfowl should not submit to it.”

  • “Through a series of questions and nature images, the speaker reveals his respect and compassion for the waterfowl whom he sees as less savage than humans.”

  • “In this poem, the speaker expresses regret for the behavior of humans, whom he sees as selfish and proud in their relationship to nature, as opposed to the waterfowl, who have a more organic kinship with the environment.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Only restate the prompt.

  • Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

  • Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

  • “In this excerpt, the author introduces characters whose interactions are complex.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

  • “Everyone reacts to the passage of time differently, with some longing for the past and others looking anxiously toward the future.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

  • “This passage features a conversation between Mr. Hathaway and Mrs. Edwards that is interrupted by a third character who is much younger than they are.”

Responses that earn this point:

  • Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex interactions among the characters.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

  • “By showing Mr. Hathaway and Mrs. Edwards interacting with the young mother, the author suggests that these characters don’t fully appreciate their own stage of life.”

  • “In this passage, each character longs for the kind of life that the other has.”

  • “The author uses dialogue throughout the excerpt to establish Mr. Hathaway and Mrs. Edwards as characters who easily relate to each other’s perspectives on time and aging, unlike the young mother.”

Restate the prompt

  • “The outsider is a classic character in literature. The feeling of not belonging, whether within one’s family, society, or even one’s self can really affect the character.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment about the selected work

  • “In The Bell Jar by Sylvia Plath, Esther struggles to find her place both with her family in Massachusetts and during her internship in New York City.”

  • “The García sisters—Carla, Yolanda, Sandra, and Sofia—experience two cultures, that of the Dominican Republic and that of the United States.”

Responses that earn this point:

  • Provide a defensible interpretation of how the experience of feeling out of place affects the character.

    OR

  • Make a claim about how the experience of feeling out of place affects the character and contributes to an interpretation of the work as a whole.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

  • “In Mary Shelley’s Frankenstein, when Victor destroys the Creature’s companion, robbing him of his one chance at finding a place in the world, the Creature, in vengeance, robs Victor of everything dear to him, isolating Victor just as he is isolated.”

  • “In Americanah, Ifemelu’s experiences in the U.S. show that a shared racial identity does not necessarily create a sense of belonging.”

  • “Holden Caulfield’s earnest, yet failed, search to find true connection in a world of ‘phonies’ leaves him feeling more alone with each disappointment. It is this growing disillusionment that conveys the novel’s commentary on coming of age and realizing the superficiality of society.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Typical responses that earn 0 points:

  • Are incoherent or do not address the prompt.

o.d:

Notes for this rubric row:

  • This point should be awarded only if the sophistication of thought or complex understanding is part of the student’s argument, not merely a phrase or reference.

o.d: The response does not demonstrate sophistication of thought nor develop a complex literary argument.
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Attempt to contextualize their interpretation, but such attempts consist predominantly of sweeping generalizations (“Human experiences always include…” OR “In a world where…” OR “Since the beginning of time…”).

  • Only hint at or suggest other possible interpretations (“While another reader may see…” OR “Though the text could be said to…”).

  • Oversimplify complexities of the topic and/or the selected work.

  • Use complicated or complex sentences or language that is ineffective because it does not enhance the student’s argument.

Responses that earn this point may demonstrate a sophistication of thought or develop a complex literary argument by doing any of the following:

1. Identifying and exploring complexities or tensions within the selected work.

2. Illuminating the student’s interpretation by situating it within a broader context.

3. Accounting for alternative interpretations of the text.

4. Employing a style that is consistently vivid and persuasive.

Notes for this rubric row:

  • The thesis may be more than one sentence, provided the sentences are in close proximity.

  • The thesis may be anywhere within the response.

  • For a thesis to be defensible, the poem must include at least minimal evidence that could be used to support that thesis; however, the student need not cite that evidence to earn the thesis point.

  • The thesis may establish a line of reasoning that structures the essay, but it needn’t do so to earn the thesis point.

  • A thesis that meets the criteria can be awarded the point whether or not the rest of the response successfully supports that line of reasoning.

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Only restate the prompt.

  • Make a generalized comment about the poem that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

  • Describe the poem or features of the poem rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

  • “Lines can be very complex, and Delgado uses several techniques to communicate this.”

  • “In ‘Peculiar Properties,’ Delgado writes about lines by describing a line of ants in a kitchen.”

Do not relate to the prompt

  • “This poem vividly illustrates a common household annoyance—ants invading a kitchen.”

Describe the poem or features of the poem

  • “The narrator of this poem presents a first-person point of view description of watching ants marching across his cutting board, which then causes him to recall a lesson from his sixth-grade teacher.”

Responses that earn this point:

  • Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex nature of lines.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

  • “Juan Delgado uses the line of ants in the speaker’s kitchen to symbolize the unseen connections between people.”

  • “The first two stanzas of the poem show a moment that seems unimportant at first—the ants on the speaker’s cutting board—but the last two stanzas suggest how seeing the line of ants made the narrator feel connected to his wife.”

  • “The image of the ants as a dotted line and the teacher’s math lesson about lines convey that despite our constant searching there is a larger dynamic at work that already involves us.”

o.d: The response demonstrates at least one of the following:
o.af:
Responses that do not earn this point:

  • Only restate the prompt.

  • Make a generalized comment about the passage that doesn’t respond to the prompt.

  • Describe the passage or features of the passage rather than making a claim that requires a defense.

Examples that do not earn this point:

Restate the prompt

  • “In this excerpt from Mansfield Park, Austen creates a complex characterization of Mrs. Norris by using literary techniques.”

Do not respond to the prompt but make a generalized comment

  • “Relationships between family members can become very complicated when important decisions have to be made.”

Describe the passage or features of the passage

  • “In this excerpt, Mrs. Norris discusses arrangements for her niece with her sister and brother-in-law, and they eventually figure out a plan that works for everyone.”

Responses that earn this point:

  • Provide a defensible interpretation of the complex characterization of Mrs. Norris.

Examples that earn this point:

Provide a defensible interpretation

  • “Austen characterizes Mrs. Norris as someone who pretends she will do anything for her family and is also unaware of her own shortcomings.”

  • “Austen uses irony and humor to suggest that Mrs. Norris’s sense of her own generosity is at odds with her actual stinginess and refusal to help with her niece’s care.”

  • “Austen contrasts Mrs. Norris with her sister and brother-in-law to emphasize her manipulative approach to resolving family matters. She takes advantage of Lady and Sir Thomas Bertram’s kindness, so she doesn’t have to take responsibility for her niece.”
